dt.t: spends a lot of time {wi}haunting{/wi} bookstores
impostors that {wi}haunt{/wi} the official in foreign ports

dt: {bc}to have a disquieting or harmful effect on {bc}{sx|trouble||}

dt.t: problems we ignore now will come back to {wi}haunt{/wi} us
a sense of tension that {wi}haunts{/wi} his writing

dt: {bc}to visit or inhabit as a ghost

dt.t: Spirits are supposed to {wi}haunt{/wi} the places where their bodies most resorted …
not far from … where she {wi}haunted{/wi} appeared for a short time a much more remarkable spirit

et: Middle English {it}haunten, hanten{/it} "to frequent, frequent the company of, dwell in, engage in, practice (a vice or virtue), perform," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}hanter{/it} (also continental Old French), of uncertain origin

The origin of the French word has been much argued over in the past century and a half. Given the initial {it}h aspiré{/it} (meaning the initial {it}h{/it} was pronounced into early modern French and still blocks elision of preceding vowels), the word has usually been given a Germanic source. Perhaps most frequently it has been traced to the Old Norse verb reflected in Old Icelandic {it}heimta{/it} "to draw, pull, call on, claim, crave, get back, recover," despite semantic and phonetic objections. Also proffered has been a presumed Old Low Franconian {it}*haimiþōn{/it} "to shelter, accommodate." Both etyma are derivatives of Germanic {it}*haima-{/it} "dwelling" (see {et_link|home:1|home:1}). The possibility of a spoken Latin source has been revived in {it}Dictionnaire étymologique de l'ancien français{/it} (on line), which suggests {it} *ambitāre,{/it} from Latin {it}ambitus{/it} "circuit" (see {et_link|ambit|ambit})—see full discussion and bibliography there.
shortdef: to continually seek the company of
to have a disquieting or harmful effect on : trouble
